      • setTargetPriorities

        public void setTargetPriorities(float xPriority,
                                float yPriority,
                                float zPriority)
        Sets the priority of the orientation bases which effectors reaching for this target will and won't align with. If all are set to 0, then the target is treated as a simple position target. It's usually better to set at least on of these three values to 0, as giving a nonzero value to all three is most often redundant. This values this function sets are only considered by the orientation aware solver.
        Parameters:
        position -
        xPriority - set to a positive value (recommended between 0 and 1) if you want the bone's x basis to point in the same direction as this target's x basis (by this library's convention the x basis corresponds to a limb's twist)
        yPriority - set to a positive value (recommended between 0 and 1) if you want the bone's y basis to point in the same direction as this target's y basis (by this library's convention the y basis corresponds to a limb's direction)
        zPriority - set to a positive value (recommended between 0 and 1) if you want the bone's z basis to point in the same direction as this target's z basis (by this library's convention the z basis corresponds to a limb's twist)

      • getSubtargetCount

        public int getSubtargetCount()
        Returns:
        the number of bases an effector to this target will attempt to align on.

      • alignToAxes

        public void alignToAxes(AbstractAxes inAxes)
        translates and rotates the pin to match the position and orientation of the input Axes. The orientation is only relevant for orientation aware solvers.
        Parameters:
        inAxes -

      • getPinWeight

        public float getPinWeight()

      • setPinWeight

        public void setPinWeight(float weight)
        Currently only works with tranquil solver.
        Parameters:
        weight - any positive number representing how much the IK solver should prefer to satisfy this pin over competing pins. For example, setting one pin's weight to 90 and a competing pins weight to 10 will mean the IK solver will prefer to satisfy the pin with a weight of 90 by as much as 9 times over satisfying the pin with a weight of 10.
